e4: Given that some investors will continue to apply the previous EPS adjustment, reporting true earnings without warning of this change riskily exposes ABC to misprices and potential retail investor losses. Retailors may react pessimistically leading the price drop so, considering retail loss, the new current business ethics for company success means preserving reported value over accurate. For the moment it seems safer to maintain an adjusted accounting practice despite being biased.
e5:
In considering a reporting policy as 'ethical', I would view the followings characteristics as important:
Timely accuracy, reflecting real economic situations.
directness in communication. Not omitting any pertinent details and avoiding to make assumptions or implications about what should have been disclosed. providing clarity on methodology used. In addition for consistency over time and avoiding surprise due the policy changes (unless unavoidable). Furthermore, reporting transparency by providing access to all factual data which otherwise not directly disclosed through typical methods; even when it is true that some data sets can require sensitive handling.
Finally being honest or not engaging deceitful practices such mis-stating values.
e6:
Yes. Two follow-up questions for the management team:
1. What are the consequences of reporting true earnings without warning, in case some stakeholders do not make the adjustment and others do? Would there be any implications for ABC's compliance or reporting obligations?
2. Have you considered any other ways to address investor misconceptions about the reported figures, such as more transparent earnings guidance or regular updates on the company's performance?
